questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the Global Enqueue Service and Global Enqueue Service (GES) Resources in Oracle 12c RAC?

choices.E: The mastering instance for a GES resource is never the same as the instance that owns an enqueue in shared mode.
choices.G: The foreground process on the requesting instance communicates with the LMD0 process on the mastering instance if they are not the same instance.
choices.C: When a GES resource is dequeued, converters if any exist for that resource, are processed before any waiter for that resource.
choices.D: The LMD0 process on the requesting instance communicates with the LMD0 process on the mastering instance if they are not the same instance.
choices.A: The mastering instance for a GES resource is never the same as the instance that owns the enqueue in exclusive mode.
choices.F: An LMD0 process runs on all instances.
choices.B: The LMD0 runs only on the instance that masters all GES resources.

discussion.content: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/F49540_01/DOC/server.815/a67778/ch5_inst.htm foreground processes communicate lock requests directly to remote LMD processes.

why this is wrong?
F. An LMD0 process runs on all instances.
In my opinion DEF is correct
FG process never communicate with LMD on remote instance, its always LMD to LMD communication

Selected Answer: BE
B. AR is available on any one available CDB1 instance in prod_pool at any one time. 
E. AR can fail over to any other available CDB1 instance in prod_pool, not any of CDB(6 hosts) instances.

A no; a singleton service runs in only one instance
B no; a singleton service is available in only one instance, though it's true that the instances of CDB1 runs all in hosts in prod_pool
C yes: a singleton service runs in only one instance, though it can failover to only one same database instance
D no; service creation and service starting does not have to take place in the same node of command execution
E yes; can fail over to any other instance of CDB1 database, and this database runs in the three hosts that belong to prod_pool
sorry b and E not b and c

it is B,C
it is cardinality singleton mean that will be run on only one instance at a time and choose from server pool active then failover if instance fails

choices.A: AR runs as a singleton service in the server pool prod_pool and the AR service is available in each of the CDB1 instances.
choices.C: AR can fail over to any one of the available CDB1 instances.
choices.E: AR can fail over to any other available CDB1 instance in prod_pool.
choices.B: AR is available on any one available CDB1 instance in prod_pool at any one time.
choices.D: AR is available only on the CDB1 instance on HOST01.

questions.question_text:
You administer a six-instance, policy-managed, multitenant RAC database CDB1 with three PDBs: PDB_1, PDB_2 and PDB_3.
Server pool prod_pool has a cardinality of three and all six hosts of the cluster app.
Examine these commands executed on HOST01:
$ srvctl add service db CDB1 pdb PDB_1 service AR serverpool prod_pool cardinality singleton
$ srvctl start service db CDB1 service AR
Which two statements are true regarding the AR service?

choices.C: In a RAC database, there is no LMD0 process if only one instance is running.
choices.B: Global Enqueues and Instance Locks replace mutexes completely in RAC database instances.
choices.D: Global Enqueues and Instance Locks replace latches completely in RAC database instances.
choices.A: In a RAC One Node database, there is no LMD0 process if only one instance is running.
choices.F: Global Enqueues may have converters and waiters in the same instance.
choices.E: Global Enqueues may have owners and waiters in the same instance.

discussion.content: what happens when in a One Node RAC database is needed to start a new instance for maintaining purposes? I think exists always a lmd0 process in RAC databases be One node or not; so my answer is E,F

BF,
why no LMD process in one node RAC? Its a RAC DB afterall

comments.content: no , LMD0 will lock for global lock , which is remote lock , that is mean there is another instance will access , in one node RAC there is only on instance .

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about the Global Enqueue Service, Instance Locks, and global enqueues in Oracle 12c RAC?
questions.answer_description:
F: A convert queue is a queue of locks that are waiting to be converted to particular mode, this is the process of changing a lock from one mode to another, even a
NULL is a lock. A resource has a lock value block (LVB). The Global Resource Manager (GRM) keeps the lock information valid and correct across the cluster.
Oracle 10g release 2 and beyond replaced some latch mechanisms with the mutex approach, claiming that they are faster and more efficient than traditional locking mechanisms.
Incorrect Answers:
B, D: Mutexes are objects that exist within the operating system to provide access to shared memory structures. They are similar to latches.
References:
http://www.datadisk.co.uk/html_docs/rac/grd.htm

choices.A: Each node can read only the archived logs written by itself.
choices.D: Each node archives to a uniquely named local directory.
choices.F: Each node writes to a single location on the cluster file system while archiving the redo log files.
choices.C: Each node can read the archive redo log files of the other nodes.
choices.E: Each node archives to a local directory with the same path on each cluster node.
choices.B: Nodes donâ€™t use network to archive files.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the cluster file system archiving scheme?
questions.answer_description:
AB: In a cluster file system each node can only read from and write to its own local file system.
D: Configure each node to write to a local archiving directory that is named the same on each node.
References:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/rac.112/e16795/rman.htm

discussion.content: ABD answers are for non-cluster file system. In cluster file system env correct answers are BCF.

The correct answer is: BCF
References: Oracle Database 12c R2: RAC Administration - Student guide, pag 211(6-27)

B,D correct

A. COMAPTIBLE.ASM must be 11.2 or higher and COMPATIBLE.ADVM is not specified.
B. You cannot specify HIGH in the template for an external redundant disk group.
C. Volumes can be made redundant with disk groups.
D. A standard redundant disk group must contain at least two failure groups. A highly redundant disk group should contain at least three failure groups.
E. AU size can be specified as 1MB, 2MB, 4MB, 8MB.

questions.answer_description:
The compatibility parameters COMPATIBLE.ASM and COMPATIBLE.ADVM must be set to 11.2 or higher for the disk group. A high redundancy disk group must contain at least three failure groups.
Reference:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/server.112/e18951/asmdiskgrps.htm#OSTMG10072 https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/server.112/e16102/asmdiskgrps.htm

choices.A: COMAPTIBLE.ASM and COMPATIBLE.ADVM must be set to 11.2 or higher for the DATA disk group.
choices.E: The DATA disk group must have an AU size of 1MB.
choices.C: The DATA disk group must not contain any other volume.
choices.B: The DATA disk group must not be created with external redundancy.
choices.D: The DATA disk group must have at least three failure groups.
